try to feed google with some of theese words:

java 
policy file
runtime permission
exitVM
java.lang.RuntimePermission
deny
revoke

have a look at the file
${JREHOME}/lib/securirty/java.policy

have a look at the book "Java Security" by Scott Oaks.

Bernd

>   -----Mensaje original-----
>   De: Brett Neumeier [mailto:random@...]

>   Asunto: RE: [junit] How to test a main(String[] args) method?
> 
> 
>   Someone wrote (I deleted the original message, sorry):
>   > > I whould like to test a class with a main(String[] args)
>   > > method. Depending
>   > > on the input argument it executes one thing or the other. The
>   > > problem is
>   > > that on my main(String[] args) method at the end or when it
>   > > founds an error,
>   > > the method System.exit() is invoked. So when I define 
> jUnit test cases
>   > > (methods with prefix test), jUnits only runs the first test,
>   > > because some
>   > > System.exit() was invoked.
>   > >
>   > > Is there any way to test such kind of situations?
> 
>   In general I second the suggestions made by Bernd and J. B.
>   Rainsberger.  However, that said, I think you /can/ test this as it
>   currently is coded by using a security manager.  If you run 
> the JUnit
>   test runner with a security manager present, and specify a security
>   policy that doesn't allow the application code to call 
> System.exit(),
>   then what /should/ happen is that when the code calls 
> System.exit(), a
>   SecurityException will be thrown.  You can catch that in 
> your test code.
> 
>   To me this sounds like it would be more effort than 
> following Bernd or
>   J.B.'s recommendations, but I thought I'd mention it anyway 
> in case you
>   (or someone else) want to give it a try.
> 
>   Cheers,
> 
>   bn
